title: Thom Evans
text:
Thom Evans (born 2 April 1985) is a former Scottish <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">international</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player and model. He last played on the <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%2314.%20%26amp%3B%2011.%20Wing">wing</a>
for <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> in the <a href="Pro14">Celtic League</a>. Evans' rugby career ended aged 24 on his tenth appearance for Scotland when he suffered a serious neck injury.
Rugby career.
Evans was born in 1985, the second of two sons, in <a href="Harare">Harare</a>, <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, and educated at <a href="Windlesham%20House%20School">Windlesham House School</a> and <a href="Wellington%20College%2C%20Berkshire">Wellington College, Berkshire</a>. He earned his first <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a> for the Scottish rugby union side in June 2008 vs <a href="Argentina%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Argentina</a>. He was selected in the pre 6 Nations 30-man squad for the <a href="2008%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2008 Six Nations</a>.
Evans represented England at U16, U18 and U21 level. He chose to commit to Scotland at <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">A level</a> and at 7's. He could have played for the England 7's team but was ruled out through injury.
Evans was a member of pop band Twen2y4Se7en and toured as a support act with <a href="McFly">McFly</a>, <a href="Peter%20Andre">Peter Andre</a> and <a href="Westlife">Westlife</a> throughout 2004.
In the <a href="Six%20Nations%20Championship">Six Nations</a> game against <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> on 13 February 2010, Evans suffered a severe neck injury after colliding with Welsh player <a href="Lee%20Byrne">Lee Byrne</a>. He was stretchered off the pitch and taken to hospital to receive treatment. He underwent a neck operation that evening, and underwent a second operation to further stabilise his spine later that week. It was revealed that his cervical vertebrae had been knocked so badly out of alignment that he was a millimetre from paralysis or death. After four months of rehabilitation, Evans was forced to retire on 1 July 2010, after accepting medical advice.
Evans officially announced his retirement from all codes of rugby after the Wales v <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a> test match in the <a href="End%20of%20year%20rugby%20tests">Autumn Internationals</a> of 2010. After a touchline interview with television presenter <a href="Hazel%20Irvine">Hazel Irvine</a>, Evans outlined his intentions to return to the sprinting circuit, in the hope of other athletic success.
In 2012, Evans, coached by Margot Wells, kick-started his athletic campaign competing in indoor competitions and finished fourth in the Scottish Senior Championships with a personal best of 7.20 for the 60m. During the outdoor season, he ran personal bests of 11.26 for the 100m and 23.14 for the 200m respectively. However, by the end of the season, Evans decided that he would not continue with athletics choosing instead to pursue an acting career.
Media career.
Evans was an analyst for <a href="ITV%20Network">ITV</a>'s coverage of the <a href="2011%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2011 Rugby World Cup</a>.
In September 2014, Evans was a contestant in BBC's <a href="Strictly%20Come%20Dancing%20%28series%2012%29">twelfth series</a> of "<a href="Strictly%20Come%20Dancing">Strictly Come Dancing</a>" partnered with Lithuanian professional Iveta Lukosiute. He was voted out in the 5th week.
In 2016, Evans participated in the first series of the TV show "<a href="Celebrity%20Island%20with%20Bear%20Grylls">Celebrity Island with Bear Grylls</a>", with celebrity contestants attempting to survive for 10 days on a remote island. He left the island early citing difficulties dealing with the lack of food.
In October 2019, Evans was a contestant in "" as a member of the group, Try Star, alongside <a href="Levi%20Davis">Levi Davis</a> and <a href="Ben%20Foden">Ben Foden</a>. They were eliminated in the semi-final after landing in the bottom two with V5. However, Try Star received more votes than V5 meaning if the result went to deadlock, Try Star would have advanced to the final and V5 would have been eliminated. They finished in fifth place.
Personal life.
Evans' brother <a href="Max%20Evans%20%28rugby%20player%29">Max</a> also played rugby for Scotland and <a href="Castres%20Olympique">Castres</a>. They are the twentieth set of brothers to play together for Scotland. They are both featured in a nude photoshoot for the 2010 "Dieux du Stade" calendar.
In 2011, he appeared on cereal boxes for <a href="Scott%27s%20Porage%20Oats">Scott's Porage Oats</a> along with <a href="Chris%20Paterson">Chris Paterson</a> and <a href="Ross%20Ford">Ross Ford</a>.
Evans is a cousin of disc jockey <a href="Chris%20Evans%20%28presenter%29">Chris Evans</a>.
Relationships.
Evans was romantically linked with actress <a href="Kelly%20Brook">Kelly Brook</a>. On 16 March 2011, Brook announced, via her Twitter account, that she was pregnant and that she and Evans were expecting a daughter. On 9 May 2011, it was reported that Brook had miscarried. Brook announced on 1 February 2013 via Twitter that she and Evans had broken up.
In January 2020, it was reported that Evans was dating singer <a href="Nicole%20Scherzinger">Nicole Scherzinger</a>, having met on "The X Factor: Celebrity" the previous year.
